Introduction

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly fatal neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions.

Pathophysiology



CJD is caused by prions, the only known infectious agents that lack nucleic acids (eg, DNA, RNA).  Prion protein (PrP) is found in both neuronal and nonneuronal brain cells and normally exists in an alpha-helical structure (PrPC).  Prion diseases occur after a domain in this protein undergoes a conformational change from an alpha helix into a beta pleated sheet isoform (PrPSC), which confers the ability to induce similar conformational changes in other proteins.  This beta sheet conformation is resistant to proteases and forms long, highly neurotoxic fibrils that accumulate intracellularly in neurons and form extracellular deposits.  This results in noninflammatory spongiform neurodegeneration with widespread loss of neurons throughout the cerebrum and cerebellum.

Pathology



On microscopy, there is spongiform degeneration of the gray matter, which is characterized by formation of microscopic vacuoles within the neuronal processes.  This leads to widespread neuronal loss and reactive gliosis without associated inflammation.  This may be evident on gross pathology as widespread atrophy involving both the cerebrum and cerebellum (in contrast to many other neurodegenerative diseases that spare the cerebellum).

Epidemiology and risk factors



Most cases of CJD occur in patients age >50 and are sporadic with no clearly identifiable cause.  However, known risk factors for developing nonsporadic forms of CJD include:



  • Genetic mutations in the prion protein (PRNP) gene (eg, genetic CJD)
  • Medical procedures involving contaminated materials such as neurosurgical instruments, corneal transplants, dura transplants, or growth hormone administration (eg, iatrogenic CJD)
  • Consumption of contaminated beef from cattle with prion disease (eg, variant CJD)

Clinical presentation



Clinical manifestations of CJD are diverse and often include:



  • Neuropsychiatric decline, characterized by behavioral abnormalities, personality changes, and sleep disturbances (eg, insomnia, hypersomnia).  Patients often decline rapidly to severe dementia and an inability to care for themselves.
  • Myoclonus, classically provoked by a startle and occurring in most patients with CJD at some point during the illness.
  • Cerebellar signs, including nystagmus and ataxia (wide-based gait).
  • Upper motor neuron signs (eg, hyperreflexia, upgoing Babinski) due to degeneration of the corticospinal tracts.
  • Extrapyramidal signs, including bradykinesia and dystonia.


Although CJD has a long incubation period (estimated mean of 10 years), once symptoms occur, patients experience an inexorable decline (eg, loss of speech, loss of ability for self-care, coma) until death, which occurs less than 12 months after diagnosis.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of CJD is made by a combination of clinical findings and other supportive tests:



  • MRI of the brain often reveals hyperintensity (in DWI or FLAIR sequences) of the cerebral cortex (ie, cortical ribboning), putamen, head of the caudate, and thalamus (ie, hockey stick sign).
  • Electroencephalography (EEG) can show a characteristic pattern of synchronous, periodic sharp wave complexes.
  • CSF analysis may show elevated 14-3-3 protein, tau protein, and positive real-time quaking-induced conversion (RT-QuIC) test.


Because CJD is noninflammatory, standard CSF findings are often unremarkable (ie, no white blood cells, normal glucose, normal or mildly elevated protein).  Elevated 14-3-3 protein titers are a marker of neuronal cell death not specific for CJD, and elevated tau protein can also be seen in other neurodegenerative diseases.



Although not widely available, a RT-QuIC test can be performed, which has significantly greater sensitivity and specificity for CJD.  In this test, abnormally folded proteins are isolated, amplified, and then incubated with normally folded proteins; a prion-induced conformational change in the normal proteins can then be observed in real time via fluorescence detection.  A positive CSF RT-QuIC confirms a diagnosis of CJD.



Patients who die from probable CJD may undergo autopsy for definitive pathologic confirmation and to look for an identifiable source in possible acquired cases (eg, bovine transmission).

Differential diagnosis



  • Alzheimer disease:  can present with cognitive decline; however, in contrast to CJD, Alzheimer disease has a gradual onset (years vs months).  In addition, myoclonus and upper motor neuron signs are more characteristic of CJD.
  • Herpes simplex viral encephalitis:  can present with rapidly worsening mental status.  However, it typically manifests much faster (ie, <1 week) than CJD and is usually accompanied by fever, headache, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits.
  • Parkinson disease dementia (PDD) and Lewy body disease (LBD):  can cause behavioral changes and cognitive impairment.  However, PDD is typified by bradykinesia, resting tremor, and rigidity, and LBD is characterized by hallucinations and parkinsonism.  In addition, CJD typically worsens more rapidly than PDD and LBD.
  • Autoimmune encephalitis:  can present with rapidly progressive behavioral changes, memory dysfunction, and abnormal movements.  However, it typically occurs in conjunction with a tumor or after an infection; MRI, CSF, and EEG findings can differentiate this from CJD.

Management



There is no known treatment for CJD.  Only supportive treatment is available, which should include symptom-based management, compassionate education, and referral to social services.

Prognosis



CJD is invariably fatal, with a median survival time of 4-6 months from symptom onset (with most dying within 6-12 months).  Early diagnosis can help in planning supportive care, but it does not alter the disease course.

Summary
